You need to provide more detail: your operating system, your Eclipse version, etc.

(In reply to comment #1)
> You need to provide more detail: your operating system, your Eclipse version,
> etc.

OS: Windows XP
Eclipse version:3.1

It seems that it is not the right for posting such questions. Would you please tell me on which component to post.

Thank you in advance,
Le?la
Did you try the asking the newsgroups first?
This occurs when the JRE does not have an approprate XML parser or serializer configured.  Which JRE (and which version) are you using?

The relevant section of the trace is:

Root exception:
java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError:
org/apache/xml/serializer/OutputPropertiesFactory

It can also happen when you've got one version of xerces.jar in your code, and another version in jre/lib/ext/ as well. I'd suggest looking in the VM's ext directory to see if you've put an XML parser in there in the past, and if so, try removing it first. Also have a look for the existence of a file jaxp.properties file, and what settings (if any) there are against the XML parsers.

(In reply to comment #4)
> This occurs when the JRE does not have an approprate XML parser or serializer
> configured.  Which JRE (and which version) are you using?

I have jre1.5.0_03.

All I have as Jars under C:\Program Files\Java\jre1.5.0_03\lib\ext, are:
dnsns, sunpkcs11, localedata, and sunjce_provider.
And there is no xerces.jar in jre1.5.0_03lib/ext of my VM

How to configure appropriately an XML parser or a serializer?

I don't get the error of not finding the OutputPropertiesFactory
I have the source file of that class under com/sun/org/apache/xml/internal/serializer in my jdk directory.

Hope these are sufficient information.

BR,
Le?la
*** Bug 122889 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

By default the XML parser should be configured properly without you doing anything. In Java 5.0, The XML parser is in rt.jar, so something about your JRE or bootpath looks like it must be pointing to an alternate XML implementation. Please try a clean install of the JRE.

(In reply to comment #9)
> By default the XML parser should be configured properly without you doing
> anything. In Java 5.0, The XML parser is in rt.jar, so something about your JRE
> or bootpath looks like it must be pointing to an alternate XML implementation.
> Please try a clean install of the JRE.

Hello, I'v e done so.

But, I have a worse problem. When I try to launch eclipse, I have a "open File - Security Warning" window, with the following message:

The publisher could not be verified. Are you sure you want to run this software? (.....Unkown publisher....)

And if I dare to run it, I get plenty of errors.....

Concerning JRE, should I place in my classpath? (I have the JDK)

Thank you again,
Le?la

I don't think the security warning is coming from Eclipse - sounds like a security manager/setting specific to your computer. Can you run any Java programs using the JDK/JRE from the command line?

Marking as invalid, as this seems like a setup issue. Please see the getting started section of the Eclipse FAQ - http://www.eclipse.org/eclipse/faq/eclipse-faq.html#users
